title: 109_s765
content: The Act may be cited as the "Math and Science Incentive Act of 2005". Congress finds that the United States needs to prioritize science and mathematics education to maintain a strong scientific and technical enterprise. The current performance of US students in these fields lags behind international peers, and more students need to pursue careers in science and mathematics. The US must recommit to leadership in science, mathematics, and engineering, especially with advancements like nanotechnology. Loan forgiveness programs may be implemented to attract talent in these fields. A loan forgiveness program can attract students to careers in science, mathematics, engineering, and technology, helping the United States maintain its technological leadership. Establishment of program. The Secretary will implement a program to cover interest payments on loans for eligible borrowers who are teachers in STEM fields or professionals in STEM disciplines. Eligibility criteria include being a new borrower and having obtained loans as an undergraduate student. The program covers interest payments on loans for eligible borrowers who are teachers in STEM fields or professionals in STEM disciplines. Eligibility criteria include being a new borrower and having obtained loans as an undergraduate student. Participants must complete 5 years of service in a specified position. The Secretary will not make payments for interest that accrues before the repayment period or before signing the agreement. Selection is based on national security, homeland security, and economic security needs. The program covers interest payments on loans for eligible borrowers in STEM fields or disciplines. Selection criteria include completion of a 5-year service obligation and remaining in science, mathematics, or engineering. Loan interest availability is subject to appropriations. The Secretary will prioritize interest payments for qualified applicants based on availability of appropriations. Regulations may be prescribed as needed. Interest payments will be made for a period starting from the agreement date, continuing after service completion, and ending upon loan repayment, reaching $10,000 payment, or if service obligation is not fulfilled. The borrower must fulfill the service obligation for 5 years, or repayment is required if income exceeds 4 times the national per capita income. The Secretary will pay interest to eligible lenders for student borrowers selected under the program. Application for repayment is required. The borrower must complete 5 years of service or repay the Secretary if income exceeds 4 times the national per capita income. Eligible individuals must submit an application for loan interest payment, agreeing to repay if service requirements are not met. Consolidation loans may qualify for interest payment if used for repayment by eligible borrowers. The borrower can use the loan amount to repay certain types of loans under specific sections of the Higher Education Act. Borrowers cannot receive benefits from both this section and other loan forgiveness programs for the same service. The Act defines key terms such as "Secretary" and "mathematics, science, or engineering professional." It also authorizes appropriations for the Act for fiscal year 2006 and the following 5 years.
